Abstract of the bachelors thesis
 
Author Henrik Aalto
 
Title The Sylow Theorems and Classication of Finite Groups
 
Degree programme Bachelor of Science in Technology

Abstract
 
A group is, by denition, a simple mathematical structure from which stems a
 
complex and fruitful branch of mathematics. Two natural examples of groups are
 
the states of the Rubiks cube and the integers modulo
 
n
 
,
 
Z
 
n
 
. The power of groups
 
lies in their ability to eectively model very fundamental systems: symmetries and
 
their combinations. Group-theoretic research has traditionally focused on the precise
 
classication of groups. In this approach, the specic elements of a group do not
 
matter, rather, it is only the relationships among the elements that determine the
 
class of the group. The so-called group axioms impose strict constraints on the
 
structure. By studying this structure, one obtains classication results that have
 
direct applications in crystallography and number theory.
 
In this bachelors thesis, the classication of groups of order up to 20 is examined
 
in detail, starting from the denition of a group. Central results of group theory and
 
the precise examination of the structure of small groups are central in the work. As
 
aids for classication, additional structures related to groups are dened, such as
 
subgroups and cosets. Through these, we obtain access to Sylows theorems and the
 
fundamental theorem of nite Abelian groups, both of which are powerful tools for
 
constraining the possibilities of classication. On the other hand, new isomorphism
 
classes can be constructed by forming semidirect products between smaller groups.
 
With dierent constructions, there is a need to distinguish between isomorphic and
 
non-isomorphic groupsa task for which comparing the sizes of normal subgroups
 
and the orders of elements proves useful. Each approach to classication reinforces
 
our understanding of the potential realisations of groups.
 
The classication of Abelian groups is achieved via the fundamental theorem,
 
yet even the structures of small non-Abelian groups can dier markedly from one
 
another. Nonetheless, groups always adhere to certain regularities, and often some
 
additional constraint uniquely determines the remainder of the groups structure.
 
There is one isomorphism class of groups of order seven, whereas there are ve
 
isomorphism classes of groups of order eight. Thus, the number of isomorphism
 
classes does not depend directly on the order of the group. Instead, this number is
 
strongly connected to the prime factorisation of the order: the more factors a number
 
has, the more isomorphism classes of that order there are. Groups of composite order
 
can be assembled in various ways from smaller groups, while, as an extreme example,
 
every prime order corresponds to only one isomorphism class consisting solely of the
 
cyclic group. A number-theoretic approach can be further pursued by investigating
 
4
 
the isomorphism classes for groups of orders
 
pq
 
and
 
p
 
2
 
, where
 
p
 
and
 
q
 
are primes.
 
For the former, there are one or two classes, whereas for the latter there are always
 
exactly two possibilities. This result further strengthens the connection between the
 
prime factorisation of the order and the structure of the group.
 
Keywords
 
Group, Sylows theorems, classication, isomorphism, Lagranges theorem

1 Introduction
 
Symmetry is a fundamental principle with immense applications. It appears through-
 
out natural sciences, especially in the study of mathematics.
 
A group is the mathematical model for symmetry. The concept of an abstract
 
group has appeared in a variety of elds of mathematics and science since the 19th
 
century. Groups can represent any set of objects that when combined yield another
 
object from the same set, given that combining is associative, that there is an identity
 
object which leaves all objects unchanged and that each combination is invertible.
 
For concreteness, we introduce an example group: the symmetries of a square. A
 
square can be ipped or rotated, without changing the shape. These symmetries
 
can be combined to get new symmetries. This symmetry group, also known as the
 
dihedral group D
 
8
 
, has eight elements.
 
While the elements of a group can take any form, the crucial property is how
 
they are related to each other. We are interested in classifying groups of dierent
 
structures. Two groups are considered the same if one can be turned into the other
 
by renaming elements. It is fruitful to concentrate on classifying small nite groups,
 
since this knowledge can, then, be applied to studying larger, even innite, groups.
 
For this reason, the classication of nite groups is a signicant area of mathematics
 
that has been active since the 19th century. Known mathematicians such as variste
 
Galois, Joseph Lagrange, and William Burnside have contributed to group theory. A
 
detailed history appears in Section 2.
 
Motivated by the focus on nite groups, we now state the precise aims of this
 
work. This thesis classies all nite groups of orders 1 to 20, except for the order
 
16, up to isomorphism, providing representatives of each type and proving that the
 
classication is complete. While classications of groups appear in the literature, this
 
thesis aims to provide a self-contained and accessible account of small groups. We
 
develop the foundations of group theory by studying smaller groups in more detail in
 
order to better understand larger ones. For the classication of larger groups, more
 
powerful theorems are deployed, which in turn deepen our understanding. We aim
 
to provide a coherent and comprehensive classication with a strong emphasis on
 
discussing and analysing the results. Our goal is to convey a solid understanding of
 
the structure of small groups in addition to a grip on the most important results of
 
group theory.
 
This work begins with the abstract denition of a group. To better study groups,
 
we introduce other key structures such as subgroups and cosets. The two most
 
important theorems in group theory, Lagranges theorem and the Sylow theorems,
 
are presented and applied to the classication of groups. Through constructions like
 
direct and semidirect products we are able to create new groups which is studied
 
using the theory of isomorphisms. We also classify certain innite families of groups,
 
based on the number-theoretic structure of their order. Moreover, we present the
 
fundamental theorem of nite Abelian groups that classies all nite Abelian groups.
 
For the groups, we have classied, we provide concise and fruitful descriptions by
 
providing their presentation.
 
The structure of the work is as follows. Chapter 2 provides a detailed account
 
11
 
of the two-century-long history of the classication of nite groups. Chapter 3
 
introduces fundamental results and structures from group theory, starting from
 
the denition of a group. Chapter 4 begins the actual classication, providing the
 
rigorous classication of groups of orders 110. Following that, Chapter 5 introduces
 
more powerful theorems and tools needed for further classication. Those tools
 
are then used in Chapter 6 to classify groups of orders 1120. The results of the
 
classication are presented in Chapter 7. Finally, Chapter 8 gives a summary of the
 
classication process and discusses methods, key ndings and implications.
 
2 Historical Background
 
The study of groups began indirectly through the study of polynomial equations in
 
the 18th century. After group-like structures had been introduced in several other
 
elds, the rigorous study of groups on their own began shortly after [
 
20
 
]. Notably,
 
variste Galois studied the solutions of polynomial equations by radicals. Galois
 
realised that the permutation symmetries of the roots of a polynomial equation
 
determined whether the equation is solvable by radicals. To this end, he introduced
 
the concept of a simple group, which is a group that has no non-trivial normal
 
subgroups [31].
 
Galoiss discoveries led to mathematicians starting to classify nite simple groups.
 
It was shown that all nite simple groups belong to one of four innite families or are
 
one of 26 sporadic groups [
 
27
 
]. The classication project can be seen to be started
 
by Otto Hlders 1892 article in Mathematische Annalen [
 
16
 
,
 
27
 
]. The rst stages of
 
group theory are examined before studying the classication project in detail.
 
In the late 18th century, Joseph-Louis Lagrange studied polynomial equations. In
 
his study, he considered permutations of the roots of a polynomial [
 
22
 
], which led to a
 
result that is now known as Lagranges theorem [
 
20
 
]. At around the same time, Carl
 
Friedrich Gauss studied number theory [
 
13
 
]. He proved that the group of integers
 
modulo a prime
 
p
 
equipped with multiplication,
 
Z
 
 
p
 
, is cyclic [
 
13
 
]. Gauss, however,
 
did not approach the problem through group-theoretic terms [
 
20
 
]. Galois, as stated
 
above, introduced theory similar to groups and normal subgroups in 1832 [12, 27].
 
In addition to Lagranges classical algebra and Gausss number theory, group-
 
theoretic ideas were also used to study geometry [
 
19
 
] and analysis [
 
20
 
,
 
26
 
]. The rst
 
abstract denition of a nite group was given by Arthur Cayley in 1854 in the article
 
On the theory of groups, as depending on the symbolic equation
 
 
n
 
= 1 [
 
6
 
,
 
20
 
]. Cayley
 
presented several examples of groups, and went on to prove that every nite group is
 
isomorphic to a permutation group, a result now known as Cayleys theorem [
 
20
 
].
 
Cayley even classied all groups of order 4 and 6 [6].
 
During the latter half of the 19th century, the concept of an abstract group spread
 
widely [
 
20
 
], and led to several subsequent developments. The Norwegian mathemati-
 
cian Peter Ludvig Sylow in 1872 published his famous theorems on subgroups of
 
prime-power orders [
 
27
 
,
 
29
 
]. The rst classication results are from this era as well,
 
as Camille Jordan began building a database of nite simple groups in 1870 in Trait
 
des substitutions et des quations algbriques [17, 27].
 
12
 
What accelerated the classication eorts was the JordanHlder theorem, pub-
 
lished in 1889, which states that any nite group can be written as a composition
 
series of simple groups [
 
27
 
]. This theorem allows us to break groups into simple
 
factors similar to how integers are factorised into primes [
 
1
 
]. This allowed mathe-
 
maticians to focus on classifying all simple groups, since non-simple ones can be
 
constructed from them.
 
William Burnside was the rst to publish a paper classifying an innite family of
 
nite simple groups in 1899 [
 
5
 
,
 
27
 
]. mile Mathieu was the rst to discover sporadic
 
(a term used originally by Burnside [
 
31
 
]) simple groups,
 
M
 
11
 
and
 
M
 
12
 
, in 1861 [
 
23
 
,
 
31
 
].
 
Sporadic groups are exceptions to the general classication, as all nite simple groups
 
t into one of the innite familiesapart from sporadic ones [
 
1
 
]. Mathieu later
 
constructed the sporadic groups
 
M
 
22
 
,
 
M
 
23
 
, and
 
M
 
24
 
in 1873 [
 
24
 
]. At the turn of
 
the century, Burnside and Georg Frobenius published multiple classication results,
 
including Burnsides famous
 
p
 
a
 
q
 
b
 
theorem that states that if
 
p
 
and
 
q
 
are primes, then
 
groups of order p
 
a
 
q
 
b
 
are solvable [27].
 
In the 1960s, the general belief was that all nite simple groups had been found
 
and that it only remained to prove that the list is exhaustive [
 
31
 
]. Over the following
 
decade, twenty-one further sporadic groups were discovered with the last one, the
 
fourth Janko group
 
J
 
4
 
, being discovered in 1975 by Zvonimir Janko. In the year
 
1980, it was once again believed that the classication of nite simple groups was
 
completed [
 
27
 
]. All 26 sporadic groups had been found, and there existed thousands
 
of pages of rigorous mathematical writing proving that any non-sporadic nite group
 
must belong to one of the innite families. Around 1989, Michael Aschbacher noticed
 
a aw related to the handling of so-called quasithin groups. Filling this gap in the
 
theorem proved to be more dicult than Aschbacher and Steve Smith originally
 
gured. In the end, it took over a decade to patch the theorem.
 
The proof for the classication theorem for nite simple groups (CFSG) was
 
nally completed in 2004 with two volumes from Aschbacher and Smith [
 
2
 
,
 
3
 
,
 
31
 
].
 
The classication theorem states that every nite simple group is isomorphic to one
 
of the following: a cyclic group of prime order, an alternating group of degree at least
 
5, a simple group of Lie type, or one of 26 sporadic groups [
 
1
 
,
 
28
 
]. The classication
 
theorem is considered the most important result in nite group theory [
 
1
 
]. The
 
complete proof, composed of some 500 articles, has been estimated to run between
 
10,000 and 15,000 pages [14].
 
The completion of the CFSG led to deep results in the eld of permutation theory.
 
The classic problem of classifying multiply-transitive groups followed immediately
 
from the result. However, this exceptionally large proof left mathematicians unset-
 
tled. It was the sheer size of the proof of the CFSG that made mathematicians uneasy
 
that it might contain a mistake. To this end, many proofs were being rewritten
 
and simplied [
 
27
 
]. Furthermore, Daniel Gorenstein, Richard Lyons, and Ronald
 
Solomon started writing a whole new holistic proof for the theorem [
 
1
 
]. Their eort
 
is christened the GLS project by their surnames.
 
While simple groups are fully classied, classifying arbitrary nite groups is a
 
dierent matter. Obtaining a general classication of nite groups is considered
 
unattainable, given their intrinsic complexity [
 
10
 
]. Modern developments in nite
 
13
 
group classication often involve using computational methods. The usage and
 
development of algorithms for group classication began in the 1990s [
 
10
 
]. During
 
that time, two major group classication databases were established: the GAP
 
system [
 
30
 
] and the Magma system [
 
4
 
,
 
10
 
]. These databases have replaced old physical
 
categorisations like John Horton Conways ATLAS [
 
7
 
]. One modern example of
 
computer-aided group classication is the work of Dietrich et al. on the classication
 
of groups whose orders factorise into at most four primes [8].
 
3 Preliminaries
 
3.1 Groups
 
Groups are a fundamental structure in modern algebra. We begin by giving the
 
denition of a group, presented below. A group is a simple structure that is, in
 
essence, a set equipped with a mapping that satises certain requirements. An
 
important property of the mapping is that it must map two elements of the set to
 
an element of the set, that is, the mapping must be a binary operation.
 
Denition 3.1 (Group). A group is a set
 
G
 
equipped with a binary operation
 
: G G G satisfying the following properties:
 
1
 
1. Associativity. For all a, b, c G, (a b) c = a (b c).
 
2.
 
Identity. There exists an element
 
e
 
G
 
G
 
such that for all
 
a G
 
,
 
e
 
G
 
a
 
=
 
a e
 
G
 
= a.
 
3.
 
Inverses. For each
 
a G
 
, there exists an element
 
a
 
1
 
G
 
such that
 
a a
 
1
 
=
 
a
 
1
 
a = e
 
G
 
.
 
The notation
 
(G, )
 
is used to denote the group consisting of the set
 
G
 
equipped
 
with the binary operation
 
 
:
 
G G G
 
. The operation
 
a b
 
is called the product
 
of
 
a

3.2 Subgroups
 
A group might have subsets of its elements which have a group structure of their own.
 
These subsets are called subgroups. Studying a groups subgroups often provides
 
valuable insights into the overall structure and properties of the group. Subgroups
 
prove to be an invaluable tool in group classication, since if two groups are considered
 
the same, then they must have the same subgroup structure. Conversely, if two
 
groups have diering subgroup structure, then the groups cannot be the same.

It is common practice to use the overgroups operation for the subgroup as well.
 
Often, it is not necessary to explicitly state the group operation of the subgroup,
 
since it is clear from the context.

3.4 Cosets
 
Given that groups are closed under the group operation, and that subgroups are

3.6 Isomorphisms
 
Two groups have the same structure if one can be equal to the other by renaming its
 
elements. To classify groups into classes that have the same structure, we need a
 
way to dene an equivalence relation between groups. This relation should indicate
 
whether two groups have the same structure, ignoring what specic elements they
 
contain. To this end, we dene homomorphisms and isomorphisms.
 
A homomorphism is a mapping between two groups that preserves the group
 
structure. A rigorous denition is given below.
 
Denition 3.40 (Homomorphism). Let (

dened by

Denition 3.41 (Isomorphism). A homomorphism is called an isomorphism if it
 
is bijective.

We now focus on the actual classication of groups. To get started, it is useful to

Denition 3.53 (Isomorphism class of group). Let
 
G
 
be a group. The isomorphism
 
class of G is dened as the class of groups isomorphic to G.
 
Note that any group is isomorphic to itself (by the identity map). Hence, the
 
isomorphism class of any group
 
G
 
contains
 
G
 
itself. We are looking to assign all
 
groups of some order into isomorphism classes. It is, thus, essential to note that
 
isomorphism classes actually do partition groups.
 
Proposition 3.54 (Isomorphism classes partition groups). Every group belongs to
 
some unique isomorphism class, that is, isomorphism classes partition the class of
 
all groups.
 
Proof.
 
To show that isomorphism classes partition the class of all groups, we show
 
that the relation is isomorphic to is an equivalence relation. For this, it has to
 
satisfy the following properties
 
1.
 
Reexivity. For any group
 
G
 
, we have
 
G
 
 
=
 
G
 
using the identity isomorphism.
 
2. Symmetry. Let G, H be groups. If G
 
 
=
 
H, then H
 
 
=
 
G by Proposition 3.44.
 
3.
 
Transitivity. Let
 
G, H, K
 
be groups. If
 
G
 
 
=
 
H
 
and
 
H
 
 
=
 
K
 
, then
 
G
 
 
=
 
K
 
by Proposition 3.43.
 
The relation, being an equivalence relation, partitions the class of all groups into
 
(disjoint) isomorphism classes.
 
By Theorem 3.42, two nite isomorphic groups must have the same order. Thus,
 
any isomorphism class of a nite group only contains groups of the same order,
 
since one cannot dene a bijection (isomorphism) between two nite sets (groups) of
 
dierent sizes or from a nite set to an innite set.

classes contain an isomorphic group for any group of order n.
 
This denition allows us to start classifying groups. To make things easier, we
 
rst prove some general classication theorems.

5.1 Semidirect Products
 
To classify groups of larger orders, we introduce some further results from group theory.
 
Before, we used external direct products to construct large groups from smaller ones.
 
Next, we introduce a generalisation of that: external semidirect products, which are
 
a more expressive tool for generating a wider variety of groups.
 
We rst state the denition of the internal semidirect product, and then later
 
prove that all internal semidirect products are isomorphic to external ones.
 
Denition 5.1 (Internal semidirect product of groups). Let (
 
G,
 
) be a group. We
 
say that G is the internal semidirect product of subgroups H and K if
 
1. G = HK,
 
2. H K = {e},
 
3. H G.
 
The rst condition can be replaced by
 
|G|
 
=
 
|H||K|
 
by Proposition 3.38 and the
 
second by gcd(|H|, |K|) = 1 by Proposition 3.37.
 
Note that the internal semidirect product agrees exactly with the internal direct
 
product (Denition 3.46) if, in addition to
 
H
 
, the subgroup
 
K
 
is also normal in
 
G
 
.
 
To get started with external semidirect products, we rst introduce the concept of
 
automorphisms.
 
Denition 5.2 (Automorphism). Let (
 
G,

is called an automorphism of G if its domain and codomain are G.
 
Theorem 5.3 (Automorphisms form a group). Let (

forms a group under the composition operation. This group is
 
denoted by Aut(G).
 
Proof for the above theorem is omitted here, but it is discussed in [11, 15, 18].

5.2 The Sylow Theorems
 
Note that the converse of Lagranges theorem (Theorem 3.30) is false: if some integer
 
n
 
divides the order of a group
 
G
 
, then
 
G
 
does not in general have a subgroup of
 
order
 
n
 
. The Sylow theorems, presented below, give a partial converse for Lagranges
 
theorem: they show that for some orders, subgroups are guaranteed to exist. These
 
results along with Lagranges theorem are the two most important results in nite
 
group theory [11, 18].
 
We need two denitions before we can present the Sylow theorems.
 
Denition 5.10 (Conjugate subgroups). Let (

Theorem 5.12 (The rst Sylow theorem). Let (

5.3 Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups
 
Next, follows a very fundamental classication result. Using the following theorem,
 
we are able to classify all Abelian groups of any order. The theorem shows that nite
 
Abelian groups have very specic structure.
 
Theorem 5.18 (Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups). Any nite Abelian
 
group G is isomorphic to a direct product of cyclic groups of prime-power order:
 
G

Furthermore, any nite Abelian group is uniquely determined by the number of terms
 
and the orders of the cyclic groups [11].
 
Proof for the fundamental theorem of nite Abelian groups is omitted. One
 
implication of the theorem is that all nite groups with more complex structures
 
are non-Abelian. All Abelian groups realise a very regular structure, since they are
 
merely direct products of cyclic groups.

In Chapters 4 and 6, we classied all groups of orders 120, except order 16, up
 
to isomorphism. Table 1 presents an overview of the results. In total, we found
 
54 groups (including the unclassied groups of order 16), of which 31 are Abelian
 
and 23 are non-Abelian. The number of groups increases with the order. There is a
 
single group of order 2, there are two groups of order four, 5 of order eight, and 14 of
 
50
 
order 16. However, even some large orders have only one isomorphism class. These
 
correspond to prime number orders, which always have only a single isomorphism
 
class.
 
The relative share of non-Abelian groups grows larger as the order increases:
 
Among the 18 groups of orders 110, only four (22%), are non-Abelian, and among
 
the 36 groups of orders 1120, 19 (53%) are non-Abelian. So, for the orders 1120,
 
over half of the isomorphism classes are non-Abelian. Since Abelian groups have a
 
more regular structure, this indicates that the larger the order, the more freedom
 
there is to dier from this regularity. Groups of small orders tend to have more
 
regular structure. This is further reinforced by the fact that the orders 15 give rise
 
only to Abelian groups.
 
Certain group types appeared in groups of dierent orders. A cyclic group
 
isomorphic to
 
Z
 
n
 
can be constructed for any order. This is the simplest possible
 
group structure. The group
 
Z
 
n
 
is Abelian and generated by a single element. Other
 
Abelian groups are found to be isomorphic to direct products of cyclic groups. The
 
rst occurrence of a direct product is encountered at order 4:
 
Z
 
2
 
Z
 
2
 
. Another such
 
instance occurs at orders
 
p
 
2
 
, where
 
p
 
is a prime. Each such order includes a group
 
Z
 
p
 
Z
 
p
 
. This intuition is later conrmed by the complete classication of nite
 
Abelian groups by the fundamental theorem of nite Abelian groups (Theorem 5.18).
 
The dihedral group
 
D
 
2n
 
is present for even orders, starting from order 6. The
 
smallest dihedral group
 
D
 
6
 
corresponds to the symmetries of a regular triangle, and
 
the larger ones can be thought to extend this idea: they represent symmetries of
 
regular
 
n
 
-gons. Signicantly, the dihedral groups appear for all even orders, showing
 
that there are innite families of non-Abelian groups. The presentation we gave for
 
D
 
6
 
generalised for all dihedral groups found, indicating that it could represent all
 
the groups in the family. We also classied the smallest alternating group:
 
A
 
4
 
. Such
 
recurring group structures conrm that some groups of dierent orders retain similar
 
structure.
 
8 Conclusions and Summary
 
This chapter provides an overview of the classication. First, a short recap of the
 
historical account is provided. Then, we draw conclusions from the full classication
 
eort, going over each of the tools and theorems that were applied. The structure
 
of the identied groups and the classied group families are discussed along with
 
specic classication strategies for outlier orders. Moreover, after limitations and
 
implications of our work are discussed, we conclude with nal remarks on the thesis.
 
In this thesis, we introduce and motivate the world of group theory. At rst,
 
some historical background is given for the classication eort of nite groups. Then,
 
important structures are dened along with fundamental theorems related to groups.
 
These structures and theorems are then used to classify the groups of orders 120
 
into isomorphism classes. We then recap the classication of all these groups into
 
one, and provide insights into the full classication.
 
The study of groups started in the 18th century through Lagranges study of
 
51
 
polynomial equations. After group-theoretic ideas were also applied to number
 
theory and geometry, variste Galois introduced simple groups in 1832, which led to
 
the development of nite group theory in the late 19th century. The introduction
 
of the JordanHlder theorem started a project of classifying all simple groups in
 
1889. It took over a century of work to classify all nite simple groups into innite
 
families or classify them as one of the 26 exceptions. In 2004, the classication of
 
nite simple groups was nally completedwith a gargantuan proof spanning over
 
10,000 pages. The completion of the classication project is a major milestone in
 
mathematics. While nite simple groups are fully classied, arbitrary nite groups
 
remain unclassied due to their intrinsic complexity. However, many databases of
 
concrete classications of nite groups exist, such as GAP and Magma [4, 30].
 
8.1 Summary of Classication of Orders 110
 
Starting from the denition of a group, we rst dened what it means for two groups
 
to have the same structure, that is, to be isomorphic. Isomorphisms yield a natural
 
way to examine the structural similarity of two groups. This denition of sameness
 
is core for the classication work of this thesis. We later showed that groups that are
 
isomorphic share many structural elements: for instance, the orders of the elements
 
of two isomorphic groups match, one group is Abelian only if the one it is isomorphic
 
to is. It was shown that isomorphisms divide all groups into isomorphism classes. To
 
classify groups, then, is to nd all isomorphism classes, providing an explicit example
 
of each class.
 
To be able to classify groups into isomorphism classes, we introduced structures
 
such as subgroups, cosets, and quotient groups. These allow us to better understand
 
the structure of groups. Subgroups give a way to extract smaller group structures
 
from large groups. Cosets provide a way to split all elements of the original group
 
into disjoint classes based on their relation to a certain subgroup. Quotient groups
 
are another way to establish new structure from a subgroup. These structures are
 
further deployed for proving important theorems such as Lagranges theorem and
 
Sylows theorems.
 
For constructing new groups, internal and external direct products are introduced.
 
Internal direct products are a specic way to represent the group as a product of
 
its normal subgroups. We showed that internal direct products are isomorphic to
 
external ones, which gives a way to split a group into direct product factors, given
 
there is a way to represent it as an internal product of normal subgroups. External
 
direct products behave well with isomorphisms. For instance, changing the order of
 
the factors keeps the product the same up to isomorphism. Moreover, changing any
 
of the factors does not aect the result, either.
 
Groups of orders 110 were classied using three dierent techniques. Firstly,
 
groups of prime orders were classied to be cyclic. There is only one isomorphism
 
class for any prime order. This is due to the divisibility of primes. Lagranges
 
theorem implies that the order of all group elements must divide the order of the
 
group. Since primes are only divisible by 1 and themselves, this restricts the orders
 
of the elements in the group to two choices. The denition of the order of an element
 
52
 
implies that non-identity elements must have order greater than 1.
 
Secondly, groups of order
 
p
 
2
 
were identied to have two isomorphism classes: the
 
cyclic group and the direct product of two cyclic groups of order
 
p
 
. This is a major
 
classication result, since it allows for classifying an innite family of groups. Again,
 
the result is ultimately due to the number-theoretic structure of the order. It is
 
clear that all orders have cyclic groups. To see that the only other option is a direct
 
product of two equally-sized cyclic groups, we again rely on Lagranges theorem. It
 
shows that elements of order
 
p
 
must exist in the group. The subgroups generated by
 
such elements allow us to express the whole group as an internal direct product of
 
two such subgroups. This internal direct product, then, is isomorphic to an external
 
one, which leads to the representation of the group as a direct product of two cyclic
 
groups.
 
Finally, the orders 6, 8, and 10 are classied using case-by-case work. To nd the
 
structure of the group, it is necessary to know its elements. For this, we showed that
 
an element of order
 
n/
 
2 exists in the group. Then, the subgroup generated by this
 
element contains half the elements in the group. The other half is exactly contained
 
in the only other coset of this subgroup. This gives a way to represent each item
 
in the group. This construction already xes the values of some products between
 
the group items. For the remaining relations between the group elements, we made
 
assumptions, and showed that those eventually led to either a fully determined group
 
structure or a contradiction.
 
8.2 Summary of Classication of Orders 1120
 
For the classication of groups of orders 1120, new structures were presented.
 
External direct products were powerful for classifying and representing Abelian groups.
 
To extend this idea to non-Abelian groups, semidirect products are introduced. An
 
internal semidirect product does not require all of the subgroups to be normal.
 
Similarly to the internal direct products, internal semidirect products are isomorphic
 
to their external equivalents. External semidirect products have the same group
 
elements as direct products, but work with a dierent group operation that requires a
 
homomorphism from the second factor to the automorphism group of the rst factor.
 
This homomorphism twists the items from the rst factor, yielding non-Abelian
 
results even from Abelian factors.
 
In order to better study the structure of larger non-Abelian groups, the Sylow
 
theorems were presented. The Sylow theorems give a partial converse for Lagranges
 
theorem. While Lagranges theorem states that the order of each subgroup divides the
 
order of the group, the rst Sylow theorem shows that there has to exist a subgroup
 
for some divisors of the order of the group. This eases the study of large groups,
 
since we immediately know something about their structure. The divisors for which
 
the Sylow theorems show the existence of subgroups are powers of primes. Hence, as
 
with many others, this result is, again, related to the prime-factor decomposition
 
of the order of the group. The third Sylow theorem gives strict requirements for
 
the number of so-called Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroups, which are helpful in assessing whether a
 
subgroup found using the rst Sylow theorem is normal.
 
53
 
We then present the fundamental theorem of Abelian groups that encapsulates
 
complete classication of all nite Abelian groups. The theorem states that Abelian
 
groups have a certain, regular structure: they are all external direct products of
 
cyclic groups of prime-power order. This simplies our classication work, and builds
 
certainty on the classication of Abelian groups of smaller orders.
 
Many of the orders from 1120 are classied using the same techniques as for
 
orders 110. However, using the theory of semidirect products we classied a new
 
innite family: groups of order
 
pq
 
where
 
p
 
and
 
q
 
are primes. The idea is to break
 
up the group into smaller piecessimilar to the classication of groups of order
 
p
 
2
 
.
 
We show that the group can be represented as an internal semidirect product of
 
two of its subgroups. This internal semidirect product is, then, isomorphic to an
 
external semidirect product, where the choice of the homomorphism gives us dierent
 
isomorphism classes. The trivial homomorphism, corresponding to the external
 
direct product of the factors, always exists, but additionally, if
 
p | q
 
1, we nd a
 
non-trivial homomorphism as well, yielding a non-Abelian group.
 
Some orders of groups still do not fall into any of the innite families of groups
 
we have classied. These are exactly the orders that cannot be represented as any of
 
the following:
 
p
 
,
 
p
 
2
 
,
 
pq
 
. For these orders a more general strategy is employed, where
 
we identify the existence of a Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroup based on the prime decomposition of
 
the order of the group. We then show that this subgroup is normal, which allows us
 
to represent the group as an internal semidirect product. This internal semidirect
 
product is isomorphic to an external semidirect product, which gives dierent groups
 
based on the homomorphism it is equipped with. If the homomorphism is non-trivial,
 
we nd non-Abelian groups, since the trivial homomorphism always corresponds
 
to the external direct product. Dierent non-trivial homomorphisms may generate
 
dierent groups, but it is important not to include any two isomorphic groups.
 
8.3 Limitations
 
One limitation of the work is the restriction to groups of certain orders. Since the
 
possible group structures depend heavily on the prime-decomposition of the order, it
 
is fruitful to consider a variety of dierent orders. The numbers from 120 are all
 
products of powers of at most two primes. Hence, in this work, we do not present any
 
classication for a group whose order is a product of powers of three distinct primes,
 
like 30 or 42. Classifying groups of more complex orders would help generalise results
 
and deepen the understanding of the possible structures.
 
Many tools are provided in the thesis for the classication of groups. The
 
implications and applications of these tools are not fully explored within the scope
 
of this work. Semidirect products are only briey introduced and then applied to
 
classication. To be able to use semidirect products, we need the denition of an
 
automorphism. However, the world of automorphisms is barely explored in the work.
 
Understanding automorphisms on a deeper level would help in constructing and
 
analysing semidirect products.
 
In this work, we rely on our classication results without doing algorithmic
 
verication for the classication. Computer systems such as GAP [
 
30
 
] could be used
 
54
 
to check that the computations and the nal classication are in line with an existing
 
database. Algorithmic classication would also provide insight into the structure of
 
larger groups than studied here. It would allow applying the results, such as the
 
Sylow theorems, to a more general set of groups.
 
8.4 Discussion
 
It is relatively simple to classify groups of orders up to 10, since for orders up to
 
10, the maximum number of groups of a single order is 5. However, the complexity
 
of classication increases with the order. For groups up to order 20, there exist 14
 
groups of order 16. This increase in complexity makes the classication task more
 
laborious and error-prone. Interestingly, the highest increase in order is observed
 
with powers of two. This indicates that the repeated prime factors in the prime-
 
decomposition of the order give rise to unseen complexity. This means the higher the
 
order, the more dicult the classication. For arbitrarily large groups, classication
 
is near-impossible.
 
Even if the classication of larger groups is a dierent task, it uses the same ideas
 
from smaller orders. The methods needed for understanding the classication of
 
small groups generalise to classifying larger groups. All of the tools and theorems
 
provided in this thesis are not specic to small orders, but rather can be applied
 
to nite groups of any orders. Especially, the more powerful results like the Sylow
 
theorems show their true power when used for even larger groups. It is possible to
 
represent every group of orders 120 as a semidirect product, which proves the wide
 
applicability of the technique.
 
The groups of orders 120 are elementary knowledge in group theory. Still, it
 
is fruitful to understand their inner structure well. Since there are many tools for
 
breaking a group apart into smaller pieces, a solid grasp of the structure of small
 
groups can help in analysing larger groups. There are many patterns that repeat for
 
larger and larger orders. This is visible in the construction of innite group families:
 
understanding and deriving the smallest dihedral group
 
D
 
6
 
gives a concrete basis on
 
top of which to build theory of the general case D
 
2n
 
.
 
All groups up to order 20, except for order 16, are now presented and examined, in
 
increasing order of
 
n
 
. Their structures were derived starting from
 
n
 
using foundational
 
tools such as Lagranges theorem, Sylow theorems, and semidirect products. These
 
tools, along with the classication, oer a viewpoint into the world of nite groups.
